Local Adaptivity in Federated Learning: Convergence and Consistency

Jianyu Wang†, Zheng Xu§, Zachary Garrett§, Zachary Charles§, Luyang Liu§, Gauri Joshi†

†Carnegie Mellon University, §Google Research Work performed while doing an internship at Google Research. Emails: jianyuw1@andrew.cmu.edu, {xuzheng, zachgarrett, zachcharles, luyangliu}@google.com, gaurij@andrew.cmu.edu
Abstract

The federated learning (FL) framework trains a machine learning model using decentralized data stored at edge client devices by periodically aggregating locally trained models. Popular optimization algorithms of FL use vanilla (stochastic) gradient descent for both local updates at clients and global updates at the aggregating server. Recently, adaptive optimization methods such as AdaGrad have been studied for server updates. However, the effect of using adaptive optimization methods for local updates at clients is not yet understood. We show in both theory and practice that while local adaptive methods can accelerate convergence, they can cause a non-vanishing solution bias, where the final converged solution may be different from the stationary point of the global objective function. We propose correction techniques to overcome this inconsistency and complement the local adaptive methods for FL. Extensive experiments on realistic federated training tasks show that the proposed algorithms can achieve faster convergence and higher test accuracy than the baselines without local adaptivity.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging paradigm to perform distributed machine learning model training on decentralized edge clients (e.g., mobile phones or IoT devices) under the orchestration of a central server, while keeping private training data on the client devices [1]. In the cross-device FL setting, a global model is usually trained by a collaborative process of thousands or even millions of participating clients. In each training round of FL, the central server broadcasts the global model to a random subset of clients to perform local model training, and each participated client only uploads the model parameter changes back to the server. Then, the server aggregates local changes to update the global model and continues the next round. This FL training procedure was proposed by McMahan et al. [2] as the federated averaging (FedAvg) algorithm, and widely applied in diverse applications [3, 4, 5].

Recently, Reddi et al. [6] proposed a generalization of FedAvg referred to as FedOpt. FedOpt is a flexible algorithmic framework that allows the clients and the server to choose different optimization methods (which are referred to as ClientOpt and ServerOpt) more general than stochastic gradient descent (SGD) in FedAvg. The key idea is to treat the aggregated local changes from clients as a “pseudo-gradient” and use it as input to ServerOpt when updating the global model. A few previous works explored the choices of server optimizer (ServerOpt) in the FedOpt framework. For example, Hsu et al. [7], Wang et al. [8] used SGD with momentum at the server while keeping client optimizer as SGD and observed significant empirical improvements.

Adaptive methods, such as AdaGrad [9, 10], Adam [11], have achieved superior empirical performance over SGD in centralized training of machine learning models for some applications. In particular, Adam and its variants [12, 13, 14] are widely recognized as the preferred optimizers for language-related training tasks. Motivated by their superior performance, Reddi et al. [6] studied a specific class of FedOpt, where ClientOpt is still SGD but ServerOpt uses adaptive methods. It has been validated through extensive experiments in [6, 15] that the server-only adaptive methods can achieve faster convergence than vanilla FedAvg in many federated training tasks.

Despite the success of using server-side adaptive methods, the power of adaptivity has not been fully utilized in the FedOpt framework, particularly on the client side. Instead of using adaptive methods only in ServerOpt for periodical updates per communication round, one can also choose to use adaptive methods in ClientOpt for every local iteration, or in both ClientOpt and ServerOpt. Client adaptive methods can accelerate the local convergence by better utilizing the geometric information of the local objectives. Unfortuantely, there are little to no literature exploring this promising direction. It remains an open problem whether the faster local convergence can be translated into faster global convergence and savings in communication rounds.

In this paper, we explore the usage of local adaptive methods and provide affirmative answers to the question: Can federated learning effectively use adaptive optimization methods on local clients? Specifically, our main contributions are listed as follows.

1. We identify that naively changing ClientOpt in the FedOpt framework from SGD to adaptive methods or other stateful optimizers can be problematic, as it does not define how to update client optimizer states (i.e., pre-conditioners and momentum buffers) across rounds. We propose to overcome this discontinuity issue by restarting the update of client optimizer states at the beginning of each round. This simple method enables the usage of local adaptivity in FedOpt. We also show that, on many practical training tasks, using adaptive optimizers on clients can achieve faster convergence and higher test accuracy than previous methods. color=blue!25, inline] Zheng: The previous sentence seems to be a bit vague and the logic on how it connects to the first sentence is not quite clear to me. What is the proposed method, and how did it overcome the issue described in the first sentence? Maybe just merge the two, drop the "identified" claim, and just directly describe we have a method to overcome the challenge. color=yellow!25, inline] Jianyu: Rephrase the complete part.

2. We further provide a theoretical analysis for strongly convex functions to understand the effects of various client optimizers. Our theorem suggests that performing FedOpt can be viewed as finding the fixed points of some operator 𝔼​[𝒜]𝔼delimited-[]𝒜{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}], the expression of which is determined by client optimizers. Local adaptivity can change 𝔼​[𝒜]𝔼delimited-[]𝒜{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] in a way that yields faster convergence. However, this enhanced optimization may come with the cost of a non-vanishing solution bias – the point we converge to may be far away from the global minimizer of the original objective function, as illustrated in Figure 1.

3. In order to overcome the side effects of using adaptive client optimizers, we propose (1) local correction technique that can help to mitigate the non-vanishing solution bias; (2) global correction technique that can help to perserve the fast convergence property of adaptive methods. Using one or both of them on the top of adaptive client optimizers can achieve the highest test accuracy on all considered federated training tasks.

Related Works. In terms of using adaptive methods on clients, Xie et al. [16], Karimireddy et al. [17] proposed to use the same optimizer states (pre-conditioners and momentum buffers) on all clients, which is similar to server adaptive methods in [6] and does not exploit local adaptivity. To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first to let clients separately update their optimizer states and study the effects of adaptive client optimizers. Besides, there are few recent literature [18, 19, 20, 21] also study the phenomenon that FedAvg-style algorithms can converge to a mismatched solution from the optimal one. We refer readers to Section 4 for detailed comparisons with these works. At last, within the FedOpt framework, there are many more building blocks that can accelerate the convergence or improve the practical performance, for instance, using control variates [22, 17, 23], regularizing the local objective functions [24, 25, 26], sampling important clients more frequently [27, 28, 29]. In this paper, we focus on an important but rarely studied topic – local adaptivity, which is orthogonal and complementary to the above previous works. color=blue!25, inline] Zheng: optional: I am not sure if claiming complementary is good enough or we want to be stronger on the difference, e.g., we care more of a cross-device settings with stateless clients. 2 Preliminaries

The Federated Learning Setup. In federated learning, the goal is to minimize the objective

In contrast to classic distributed learning, federated learning does not allow clients to share their local data with others or with the central server. Operator View of Client Optimizers. In this paper, we are going to use operators to represent the general optimizers on clients. In particular, for each client i𝑖i, we have the following definition.

Operator View of FedOpt. Based on Definition 1, at each round t𝑡t of FedOpt, the server broadcasts the global model 𝒙(t)superscript𝒙𝑡\bm{x}^{(t)} as an initial point to clients. Then, client i𝑖i uses 𝒜isubscript𝒜𝑖\mathcal{A}_{i} to obtain the locally updated model as follows:

Since the server optimizer does not influence the properties of 𝒜isubscript𝒜𝑖\mathcal{A}_{i} and the main purpose of this paper is to understand the effects of client optimizers, we assume ServerOpt is gradient descent (GD) unless stated otherwise, which means that each client participates every round and there is no server pre-conditioner. Our results can be naturally extended to other server optimizers and sampled clients without changing the main insights on client optimizers. 3 How to Apply Adaptive Methods on Clients

In this section, we describe the challenges of using local adaptivity in FedOpt and propose a simple, yet effective method to enable the usage of local adaptivity in FedOpt without incurring additional communication costs.

Challenge in FedOpt: Discontinuity of Client Optimizer States. According to the update rules 4 and 5 of FedOpt, we observe that FedOpt can not be directly applied to adaptive client optimizers, as it lacks the articulation of handling the initial optimizer states 𝒔isubscript𝒔𝑖\bm{s}_{i} across rounds and clients. To be specific, in FedOpt, the client updates are isolated not only from each other but also from different rounds due to the local iterations. While FedOpt uses ServerOpt to bridge the gap between local iterates in different rounds (i.e., it specifies how to obtain 𝒙(t+1)superscript𝒙𝑡1\bm{x}^{(t+1)} from {𝒙i(t,τi)}superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖\{\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,\tau_{i})}\}), it does not define how to update the initial optimizer states 𝒔isubscript𝒔𝑖\bm{s}_{i} across rounds. We refer to this problem as discontinuity of client optimizer states.

A natural but impractical idea to tackle the discontinuity problem is to let each client inherit its own client optimizer states from previous rounds. However, these previous states can be stale and inaccurate because they are evaluated at point 𝒙i(t−1,τi)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜏𝑖\bm{x}_{i}^{(t-1,\tau_{i})} and do not take account of the possibly dramatic changes from 𝒙i(t−1,τi)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑡1subscript𝜏𝑖\bm{x}_{i}^{(t-1,\tau_{i})} to the current iterate 𝒙(t)superscript𝒙𝑡\bm{x}^{(t)}. When the server only selects a random subset of clients at each round, the staleness will be further exacerbated, as one client may be disconnected from the server for multiple rounds. Besides, this solution is impossible in many applications of FL (e.g., the cross-device setting) that requires clients to be stateless and not to maintain any persistent states across rounds, due to privacy and system constraints [1]. Furthermore, one can also choose to synchronize the local optimizer states at the end of each round and use the synchronized states as the initial value for next round. For example, Yu et al. [31] has used a similar strategy to synchronize momentum buffer when the clients use momentum SGD. However, in order to aggregate and broadcast the additional optimizer states, this strategy would incur doubled or tripled communication costs compared to FedOpt with vanilla SGD client optimizer.

Our Proposal: Restarting Client Optimizer States. To work with the above challenges, we propose a simple yet effective approach. Instead of applying potentially complicated mechanisms to synchronize optimizer states across clients, we restart the updates of client optimizer states at the beginning of each round. That is, resetting the pre-conditioners to a constant and resetting the momentum buffers to zero. This strategy does not require any information from previous rounds, so it is compatible with application settings that require stateless clients. Also, it does not incur addition communication costs, as only the local model changes are aggregated.

To verify the advantage of this simple strategy, in Figure 1(b), we provide simulation results on a toy problem of quadratic functions with deterministic gradients. The result shows the restarting strategy on local AdaGrad (i.e., the green curve) can achieve significantly faster convergence speed, comparing to vanilla FedAvg (i.e., the blue curve) when the tolerance to the global optimal is relatively large. The fast convergence is also observed on practical federated training tasks (see Figure 2 and more discussions in Section 6).

4 Effects of Client Optimizers on Convergence and Consistency

Another important observation from the toy example in Figure 1(b) is that local AdaGrad converges to a point which is quite far away from the global optimum. Even if we decay the client learning rate, this inconsistency problem still cannot be mitigated or becomes even worse. In this section, we will theoretically analyze the effect of client optimizers on the convergence and provide insights into the trade-off between convergence speed and the consistency of the solution.

FedOpt Performs Fixed Point Iteration. When using the restarting strategy proposed in Section 3, the argument 𝒔isubscript𝒔𝑖\bm{s}_{i} representing the initial optimizer state in the operator 𝒜isubscript𝒜𝑖\mathcal{A}_{i} can be omitted since it is set to its default initial value and is the same on all clients. We further define an operator 𝒜​(𝒙)=∑i=1Mwi​𝒜i​(𝒙;τi,Ξi)𝒜𝒙superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝒜𝑖𝒙subscript𝜏𝑖subscriptΞ𝑖\mathcal{A}(\bm{x})=\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};\tau_{i},\Xi_{i}). Accordingly, the global update rule (see Eqn. 5) of FedOpt is equivalent to a stochastic fixed point iteration, shown as follows:

𝒙(t+1)=(1−α)​𝒙(t)+α​𝔼​[𝒜​(𝒙(t))]+α​(𝒜​(𝒙(t))−𝔼​[𝒜​(𝒙(t))])superscript𝒙𝑡11𝛼superscript𝒙𝑡𝛼𝔼delimited-[]𝒜superscript𝒙𝑡𝛼𝒜superscript𝒙𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝒜superscript𝒙𝑡\displaystyle\bm{x}^{(t+1)}=(1-\alpha)\bm{x}^{(t)}+\alpha{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}(\bm{x}^{(t)})]+\alpha(\mathcal{A}(\bm{x}^{(t)})-{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}(\bm{x}^{(t)})]) (6)

where α𝛼\alpha denotes the server learning rate and the expectation is taken over all random sources in local stochastic gradients at the current round. The deterministic version of 6 is known as Mann’s iteration [32] and will converge to the fixed points of 𝔼​[𝒜]𝔼delimited-[]𝒜{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] under certain conditions. Replacing server GD with another server optimizer can accelerate the convergence but it will not influence the properties and the fixed points of the operator 𝔼​[𝒜]𝔼delimited-[]𝒜{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}].

We will analyze the convergence of FedOpt (update rule of which is 6) in the setting where each local objective function Fi​(𝒙)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙F_{i}(\bm{x}) is Lisubscript𝐿𝑖L_{i}-Lipschitz smooth and μisubscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{i}-strongly convex. Besides, we make the following assumptions on the properties of each client optimizer 𝒜isubscript𝒜𝑖\mathcal{A}_{i} and show how the global convergence is influenced by these properties. If the client optimizer is SGD, then the contractive local operator and bounded cumulative variance properties described below follow directly from the strong convexity and smoothness of the objective function, suggesting the following assumptions are reasonable and mild.

Assumption 1 (Contractive Local Operator).

The local expected operator 𝔼​[𝒜i]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝒜𝑖{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}] is contractive, satisfying that ‖𝔼​[𝒜i​(𝐱;k,Ξ)]−𝔼​[𝒜i​(𝐲;k,Ξ)]‖2≤hi​(k)⋅‖𝐱−𝐲‖2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝒜𝑖𝐱𝑘Ξ𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝒜𝑖𝐲𝑘Ξ2⋅subscriptℎ𝑖𝑘superscriptnorm𝐱𝐲2\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};k,\Xi)]-{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{y};k,\Xi)]\right\|^{2}\leq h_{i}(k)\cdot\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|^{2} for any 𝐱,𝐲∈ℝd𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where 0<hi​(k)<10subscriptℎ𝑖𝑘10<h_{i}(k)<1 is a decreasing function of the number of local steps k𝑘k.

Assumption 2 (Bounded Cumulative Variance).

We assume the local stochastic gradient gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} is an unbiased estimator of ∇Fi∇subscript𝐹𝑖\nabla F_{i} and has bounded variance: 𝔼​‖gi​(𝐱)−∇Fi​(𝐱)‖2≤σ2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑖𝐱∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱2superscript𝜎2{\mathbb{E}}\left\|g_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})\right\|^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}. Similarly, the local operator 𝒜isubscript𝒜𝑖\mathcal{A}_{i} has bounded cumulative variance: 𝔼​‖𝒜i​(𝐱;k,Ξ)−𝔼​[𝒜i​(𝐱;k,Ξ)]‖2≤qi​(k)⋅σ2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝒜𝑖𝐱𝑘Ξ𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝒜𝑖𝐱𝑘Ξ2⋅subscript𝑞𝑖𝑘superscript𝜎2{\mathbb{E}}\left\|\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};k,\Xi)-{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};k,\Xi)]\right\|^{2}\leq q_{i}(k)\cdot\sigma^{2}, where qi​(k)>0subscript𝑞𝑖𝑘0q_{i}(k)>0 is a non-decreasing function of the number of local steps k𝑘k.

The function hi​(k)subscriptℎ𝑖𝑘h_{i}(k) in Assumption 1 measures the local training progress of ClientOpt. In intuition, when ClientOpt has faster convergence rate or takes more local steps, the output of 𝔼​[𝒜i]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝒜𝑖{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}] will be closer to the minimum 𝒙i∗superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖\bm{x}_{i}^{*}, and hence hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} will become smaller. Besides, the function qi​(k)subscript𝑞𝑖𝑘q_{i}(k) in Assumption 2 quantifies how the noise in stochastic gradients are accumulated through k𝑘k local updates. The analytical forms of hi,qisubscriptℎ𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖h_{i},q_{i} depend on the choice of ClientOpt. For example, when the client optimizer is SGD with fixed client learning rate, we formally prove in Appendix B that hi​(k)=(1−ηi​μi)2​ksubscriptℎ𝑖𝑘superscript1subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜇𝑖2𝑘h_{i}(k)=(1-\eta_{i}\mu_{i})^{2k} and qi​(k)=ηi2​ksubscript𝑞𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖2𝑘q_{i}(k)=\eta_{i}^{2}k. For adaptive optimizers, such as AdaGrad and Adam, while it is difficult to obtain the analytical form of hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i}, we empirically validate Assumption 1 in Section B.4 and found they can yield smaller hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} values than vanilla SGD.

Theorem 1 (Convergence of FedOpt and Minimizer Inconsistency).

Under Assumptions 1 and 2, the operator 𝔼​[𝒜]𝔼delimited-[]𝒜{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] is contractive and has a unique fixed point 𝐱~~𝐱\widetilde{\bm{x}}. After total T𝑇T communication rounds, the global iterates of FedOpt converge to 𝐱~~𝐱\widetilde{\bm{x}} at the following rate for some positive constant c𝑐c:

𝔼​‖𝒙(T)−𝒙~‖2≤c⋅([∑i=1Mwi​hi]T​‖𝒙(0)−𝒙~‖21−∑i=1Mwi​hi+1T​σ2​∑i=1Mwi2​qi(1−∑i=1Mwi​hi)2).𝔼superscriptnormsuperscript𝒙𝑇~𝒙2⋅𝑐superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℎ𝑖𝑇superscriptnormsuperscript𝒙0~𝒙21superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℎ𝑖1𝑇superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖2subscript𝑞𝑖superscript1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptℎ𝑖2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\|\bm{x}^{(T)}-\widetilde{\bm{x}}\|^{2}\leq c\cdot\left(\left[\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}h_{i}\right]^{T}\frac{\|\bm{x}^{(0)}-\widetilde{\bm{x}}\|^{2}}{1-\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}h_{i}}+\frac{1}{T}\frac{\sigma^{2}\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}^{2}q_{i}}{(1-\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}h_{i})^{2}}\right). (7)

In the presence of data heterogeneity, the fixed point 𝐱~~𝐱\widetilde{\bm{x}} of 𝔼​[𝒜]𝔼delimited-[]𝒜{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] is not necessarily the same as the optimum 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\bm{x}^{*} of the global objective F𝐹F. We refer to this problem as minimizer inconsistency.

Better Client Optimizers Can Accelerate the Global Convergence. Theorem 1 provides a nice connection between local and global convergence. Specifically, if clients use better client optimizers that have smaller contraction constant hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i}, then the worst-case global convergence to the fixed point 𝒙~~𝒙\widetilde{\bm{x}} can be improved, as the error bound 7 monotonically increases with hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i}. Therefore, a natural strategy to speedup the global convergence is to separately minimize hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} on each client while keeping qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} unchanged. One can achieve this by either tuning a proper learning rate for each client, or using adaptive client optimizers which could reduce the effective local condition number. Intuitively, using better client optimizers makes the operator 𝔼​[𝒜]𝔼delimited-[]𝒜{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] to be more contractive, and hence, it becomes easier to find its fixed points (as corroborated in Figure 1(a), the loss surface is better conditioned when using local AdaGrad). This acceleration effects is complementary to that of the server optimizer, which changes the form of the fixed point iteration without affecting 𝔼​[𝒜]𝔼delimited-[]𝒜{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}]. Therefore, one can use both better client and server optimizers to get the best performance, as we will later illustrate in Section 6.

The Minimizer Inconsistency Problem. Theorem 1 also shows that the speedup effects of client optimizers may come with a price: the fixed point 𝒙~~𝒙\widetilde{\bm{x}} can be different from the optimal minimizer 𝒙∗superscript𝒙\bm{x}^{*}. When the objective function is quadratic, ClientOpt is GD and all clients have the same learning rates η𝜂\eta and number of local steps τ𝜏\tau, it has been shown in [19, 20] that ‖𝒙~−𝒙∗‖=𝒪​(η​(τ−1))norm~𝒙superscript𝒙𝒪𝜂𝜏1\|\widetilde{\bm{x}}-\bm{x}^{*}\|=\mathcal{O}(\eta(\tau-1)) such that one can balance the trade-off between convergence speed and the minimizer inconsistency by gradually decaying the client learning rate. However, through a simple counterexample below, we will show that using adaptive optimizers or different hyper-parameters on clients leads to an additional gap between 𝐱~~𝐱\widetilde{\bm{x}} and 𝐱∗superscript𝐱\bm{x}^{*}, which does not vanish to zero with the learning rate. This non-vanishing bias explains our empirical observations in Figure 1(b) and calls for new techniques to overcome it.

Quadratic Example for Theorem 1. Theorem 2 shows that as long as one of the factors (i.e., client learning rate, the number of local steps, the pre-conditioners) is different across clients, then there would appear a non-vanishing gap between 𝒙~~𝒙\widetilde{\bm{x}} and 𝒙∗superscript𝒙\bm{x}^{*}. where the first term (on the right hand side) corresponds to the non-vanishing gap between 𝒙~~𝒙\widetilde{\bm{x}} and 𝒙∗superscript𝒙\bm{x}^{*}, and the second term can be omitted when the client learning rate is sufficiently small. This toy example also illustrates how local adaptivity can accelerate convergence. In particular, when the local pre-conditioners are ideal (i.e., inverse of local Hessians), FedOpt can converge to 𝒙~~𝒙\widetilde{\bm{x}} in just one round by choosing proper server and client learning rates. But if the local pre-conditioner are the same across all clients (𝑷i=𝑷subscript𝑷𝑖𝑷\bm{P}_{i}=\bm{P}), then the convergence of FedOpt will depend on the condition numbers of {𝑷​𝑯i}𝑷subscript𝑯𝑖\{\bm{P}\bm{H}_{i}\} and require multiple rounds.

Connections with Previous Works on Minimizer Inconsistency. When client learning rates, number of local steps are the same across all clients, and non-adaptive, deterministic ClientOpt are used, ‖𝒙~−𝒙∗‖norm~𝒙superscript𝒙\|\widetilde{\bm{x}}-\bm{x}^{*}\| can vanish to zero along with the learning rates. This phenomenon has been observed and analyzed by few recent literature in different forms, see [19, 21, 20]. Theorem 1 generalizes these results by allowing heterogeneous local hyper-parameters and adaptive, stochastic client optimizers. In addition, the non-vanishing bias was studied in [18] by assuming different local learning rates and local steps at clients. In this paper, we further generalize the results by showing that even when the learning rates and local steps are the same, using local adaptive methods will lead to a non-vanishing gap. We summarize the differences in Table 6 of Appendix D.

5 Correction Techniques to Overcome the Non-vanishing Solution Bias

As we discussed in Section 4, while using faster client optimizers and exploiting local structures can help improve the global convergence, this strategy results in a non-vanishing gap between the converged point 𝒙~~𝒙\widetilde{\bm{x}} and the optimal solution 𝒙∗superscript𝒙\bm{x}^{*}. Inspired by the quadratic example in Section 4, we propose (i) a local correction method that reweights local gradients before sending the client updates to the server in order to overcome the non-vanishing part of minimizer inconsistency, and (ii) a global correction method applied by the server when aggregating the client updates in order to preserve fast convergence.

Local Correction: Reweighting Local Gradients. From 10 in the quadratic example, one can observe that the non-vanishing minimizer inconsistency comes from the fact that FedOpt implicitly and improperly weights each local gradients by a matrix 𝑵i=ηi​τi​𝑷isubscript𝑵𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑷𝑖\bm{N}_{i}=\eta_{i}\tau_{i}\bm{P}_{i}. So a natural solution to overcome the non-vanishing bias is to normalize the local model changes before aggregating them on the server. Instead of sending 𝒙−𝒜i​(𝒙)=𝑵i​∇Fi​(𝒙)+𝒪​(ηi2)𝒙subscript𝒜𝑖𝒙subscript𝑵𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒙𝒪superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖2\bm{x}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x})=\bm{N}_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})+\mathcal{O}(\eta_{i}^{2}) to the server, each client can send the locally normalized version 𝑵i−1​(𝒙−𝒜i​(𝒙))superscriptsubscript𝑵𝑖1𝒙subscript𝒜𝑖𝒙\bm{N}_{i}^{-1}(\bm{x}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x})). This simple change can ensure that the first term in 10 is always zero no matter which value is the client learning rate. As a consequence, there is no non-vanishing solution bias. The local correction technique also automatically avoids the invalid solution 𝒙=𝒜​(𝒙),∀𝒙𝒙𝒜𝒙for-all𝒙\bm{x}=\mathcal{A}(\bm{x}),\forall\bm{x} by dividing the client learning rate.

The local correction technique can be extended to more general settings and work with any adaptive optimizers, such as AdaGrad, Adam. If the local model changes of a specific client optimizer can be written as 𝒙−𝒜i​(𝒙;τi)=ηi​∑k=0τi−1𝑩i(k)​∇Fi​(𝒙(k))𝒙subscript𝒜𝑖𝒙subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒙𝑘\bm{x}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};\tau_{i})=\eta_{i}\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}^{(k)}) where 𝑩i(k)superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑘\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)} is symmetric and positive-definite and 𝒙(k)superscript𝒙𝑘\bm{x}^{(k)} denotes the k𝑘k-th iterate during local updates, then we can choose the local correction matrix to be 𝑵i=ηi​∑k=0τi−1𝑩i(k)subscript𝑵𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑘\bm{N}_{i}=\eta_{i}\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)} such that

∑i=1Mwi​𝑵i−1​(𝒙∗−𝒜i​(𝒙∗))=∑i=1Mwi​∇Fi​(𝒙∗)⏟=∇F​(𝒙∗)⁣=0+𝒪​(ηi​τi)=𝒪​(ηi​τi).superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑵𝑖1superscript𝒙subscript𝒜𝑖superscript𝒙subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒙absent∇𝐹superscript𝒙absent0𝒪subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝒪subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\bm{N}_{i}^{-1}(\bm{x}^{*}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x}^{*}))=\underbrace{\textstyle{\sum_{i=1}^{M}}w_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}^{*})}_{=\nabla F(\bm{x}^{*})=0}+\mathcal{O}(\eta_{i}\tau_{i})=\mathcal{O}(\eta_{i}\tau_{i}). (11)

If the client optimizer is AdaGrad, then 𝑩i(k)superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑘\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)} is just the pre-conditioner 𝑷i(k)superscriptsubscript𝑷𝑖𝑘\bm{P}_{i}^{(k)} used at the k𝑘k-th local iteration; if the client optimizer is Adam, then 𝑩i(k)superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑘\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)} is a weighted summation of local pre-conditioners. In Section A.3, we provide the pseudo-code of finding the expression of 𝑵isubscript𝑵𝑖\bm{N}_{i} for common optimizers; and in Appendix F, we formally prove that local correction can help FedOpt with deterministic client optimizers converge to the stationary points of the original objective function (even when it is non-convex). For stochastic client optimizers, we empirically validate the effectiveness of local correction through extensive experiments in Section 6.

Global Correction: Preserving the Fast Convergence. Equation 11 shows that using the local correction technique may change the scale of the aggregated model updates. In particular, the first-order approximation of the aggregated model updates just equals to plain gradients (the first term in 11) and may lose the local pre-conditioning effects. In order to address this problem, one can use either adaptive server optimizer that are more robust to the scale of its inputs, or a novel global correction technique that can help to preserve the scale of local updates. To be specific, in global correction, the server uses 𝑵s−1​∑i=1Mwi​𝑵i−1​[𝒙−𝒜i​(𝒙)]superscriptsubscript𝑵𝑠1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑵𝑖1delimited-[]𝒙subscript𝒜𝑖𝒙\bm{N}_{s}^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\bm{N}_{i}^{-1}[\bm{x}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x})] as the pseudo-gradient of ServerOpt, where 𝑵ssubscript𝑵𝑠\bm{N}_{s} is given as 𝑵s=∑i=1Mwi​𝑵i−1subscript𝑵𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑵𝑖1\bm{N}_{s}=\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\bm{N}_{i}^{-1}. There may also exist other better choices of the matrix 𝑵ssubscript𝑵𝑠\bm{N}_{s}. As long as 𝑵ssubscript𝑵𝑠\bm{N}_{s} does not depend on the client index i𝑖i, it will not influence the fixed point, to which the algorithm converge. We name this technique as global correction, because it is applied on the server side. In order to obtain 𝑵ssubscript𝑵𝑠\bm{N}_{s}, the clients need to send the local correction matrices 𝑵isubscript𝑵𝑖\bm{N}_{i} to the server. But the server does not need to broadcast the correction matrix 𝑵ssubscript𝑵𝑠\bm{N}_{s} back. Therefore, if matrices {𝑵i}subscript𝑵𝑖\{\bm{N}_{i}\} are diagonal, then the communication cost per round of using global correction is only 1.5×1.5\times than that of without using it. color=blue!25, inline] Zheng: We should probably have one sentence talking about algorithm 1 somewhere.

6 Experiments

In this section, we summarize the experimental results and validate the effectiveness of the proposed methods. Specifically, we show that FedOpt with local adaptivity and correction techqniues can achieve faster convergence, higher test accuracy, as well as more robustness against learning rate changes than previous server-only adaptive methods.

We focus on three language-related tasks [6], which have the favored sparse structures for adaptive methods: (i) Next word prediciton using RNN on Stack Overflow (SO NWP); (ii) next character prediction using RNN on Shakespeare (Shakes. NCP); (iii) tag prediction using linear regression on Stack Overflow (SO TP). For the first two tasks, we report the validation/test accuracy. For SO TP task, we report the validation/test Recall@5. Moreover, we also evaluate the methods in image classification task on the CIFAR100 dataset [33]. The detailed descriptions (hyper-parameter tuning ranges and choices) of these federated training tasks are provided in Appendix A. Our implementation based on the Tensorflow Federated (TFF) package will be open-sourced.

Faster Convergence. In Figure 2, we first compare the training curves of different ways of using AdaGrad in FedOpt on the SO NWP training task. One can either use AdaGrad on clients, or on the server, or on both. It can be observed that using local AdaGrad can significantly speedup the convergence compared to using vanilla SGD as the client optimizer. In particular, client-only AdaGrad is even slightly faster than server-only AdaGrad. When the local epoch increases from 111 to 555, the improvement of client-only AdaGrad over server-only AdaGrad becomes more obvious. If we apply AdaGrad on both clients and the server, then FedOpt achieves the fastest convergence (about 4×4\times faster than server-only AdaGrad to achieve 20%percent2020\% validation accuracy in Figure 2a).

Higher Final Accuracy. We further report the test accuracy or Recall@5 on different training tasks in Table 1. Similar to the above discussions on faster convergence, changing ClientOpt from SGD to AdaGrad and using the restarting strategy prposed in section 3 consistently improves the test accuracy on multiple training tasks. And applying AdaGrad on both clients and the server achieves the highest test accuracy. For example, when the ServerOpt is AdaGrad, the test accuracy improves from 21.80%percent21.8021.80\% to 24.40%percent24.4024.40\% on SO NWP, and from 57.68%percent57.6857.68\% to 57.85%percent57.8557.85\% on Shakes. NCP. However, note that on the SO TP task, server AdaGrad plus client AdaGrad with the restarting strategy performs worse than server-only AdaGrad (65.7965.7965.79 versus 66.3966.3966.39). This performance degradation may come from the non-vanishing solution bias, as we discussed in Section 4.

Then, we evaluate the proposed correction techniques in Table 2 and compare the results with the best server-only adaptive methods on each training tasks (the best server optimizer is selected based on the results in [6]). On SO TP, by overcoming the non-vanishing bias, client AdaGrad with local correction can achieve much higher Recall@5 than vanilla SGD optimizer (67.0467.0467.04 versus 66.3966.3966.39). Similar improvements also appear in SO NWP and Shakes. NCP tasks. Besides client AdaGrad, our proposed methods also work for other common momentum-based adaptive optimizers (such as Adam and Yogi [13]). We present the experimental results on SO NWP in Table 3. It can be observed that our proposed method relatively improves the test accuracy of server Adam plus client SGD by 3.9%percent3.93.9\% (25.35%percent25.3525.35\% versus 24.40%percent24.4024.40\%), and vanilla FedAvg by 78.6%percent78.678.6\% (25.35%percent25.3525.35\% versus 14.19%percent14.1914.19\%).

Less Sensitive to Hyper-parameter Changes. In Figure 3, we report how the test accuracy changes with server and client learning rates on the SO NWP task. We observe that for server-only AdaGrad, there is only two out of 282828 learning rate combinations that can achieve a 20%+limit-frompercent2020\%+ test accuracy. On the other hand, using AdaGrad on both clients and server are more robust to the learning rate changes. There are 101010 out of 282828 combinations reaching a 20%+limit-frompercent2020\%+ test accuracy. The less sensitivity to learning rate changes can help people to save hyper-parameter tuning time in practice.

Comparison with the Synchronizing States Strategy. We further compare the proposed restarting optimizer states strategy to a synchronizing strategy where local pre-conditioners are synchronized after each round. Surprisingly, the additional communication in the synchronized strategy does not help and achieves even worse accuracy. For instance, on Shakes. NCP, server AdaGrad plus synchronized client AdaGrad has a test accuracy of 56.89%percent56.8956.89\%, which is lower than that of the restarting one (57.85%percent57.8557.85\%).

Results on Image Classification Task. At last, we examine the performance of the proposed methods on pathological version of CIFAR100, following the setup in [6]. The observations are similar to language related tasks. Naively using client adaptive methods in FedOpt is not guaranteed to have better performance. But when combining local adaptvity with the proposed correction techniques, the performance consistently improves. Specifically, after 800080008000 communication rounds, while server Adam plus client AdaGrad has worse test accuracy than server-only Adam (54.68%percent54.6854.68\% vs 56.64%percent56.6456.64\%), using local correction can improve the accuracy to 56.80%percent56.8056.80\%.

7 Conclusions

In this paper, we first propose techniques that enable the use of adaptive optimization methods for local updates at clients in federated learning. Through the analysis on effects of client optimizers for smooth and strongly convex functions, we show that although local adaptive methods can accelerate the convergence in some scenarios, it introduces an additional non-vanishing gap between the converged point and the optimal solution. To mitigate the side effects of using local adaptivity, we further propose local and global correction techniques. We verified the advantages of the proposed methods regarding fast convergence, better test accuracy with extensive experiments on benchmark datasets.

Appendix A Experimental Details

In this section, we describe our experimental setup in more detail. A brief summary of tunning ranges and default values for hyper-parameters are summarized in Table 4.

A.1 Training Tasks

Next-Word Prediction on Stack Overflow (SO NWP for short).

Stack Overflow is a language modeling dataset from the question and answer site, Stack Overflow. The datasets consists of questions and answers from 342,477342477342,477 unique users, each of which is treated as a client in our experiments. We perform next-word prediction task on this dataset and restrict to the 10,000 most frequently used words. The preprocess procedure of this datasets follows [6]. Specifically, we let each client only use the first 128 sentences of its local dataset, in order to avoid that clients have extremely different amount of data. Padding and truncation are used to ensure that sentences have 20 words. The metrics we report are the top-1 validation and test accuracy over the 10,0001000010,000-word vocabulary. It does not include padding, out-of-vocab, or beginning or end or sentence tokens. The neural network model we use is a RNN with single LSTM layer, which is the same as that of [6].

Tag Prediction on Stack Overfolow (SO TP for short).

Tag prediction via logistic regression is another training task on the Stack Overflow datasets. It has the same number of clients and vocabulary size as SO NWP. Besides, following the setup in [6], we use the 500500500 most frequent tags and a one-versus-rest classification strategy.

Next Character Prediction on Shakespeare (Shakes. NCP for short).

Shakespeare is another language modeling dataset built from the works from William Shakespeare. Each client corresponds to a speaking role with at least two lines. The lines of each speaking role is splitted into sequences of 80 characters, padding if necessary. The vocabulary size is 90. The neural networks model we use is the same as [6]: a RNN with two LSTM layers.

A.2 Best Performing Hyper-parameters

We report the best performed hyper-parameters in Table 5. The hyper-parameters are selected in a way such that the average validation accuracy (or recall@5) over the last 100100100 rounds achieves the highest value.

A.3 Pseudo-Codes of The Proposed Algorithms

We present the pseudo-codes for our proposed algorithms in Algorithm 1. It is worth noting that Algorithm 1 only provides a concrete specification of the proposed local and global correction techniques. Beyond our choices, there may exist many other algorithmic variants.

Appendix B Justifications of Assumptions 1 and 2 for Vanilla SGD Client Optimizer

B.1 Two Useful Lemmas

Before we dive into the proofs, we would like to first introduce two useful lemmas, which will be repeatedly applied later on.

Lemma 1.

Suppose function F𝐹F is twice-differentiable. Then, for any points 𝐱,𝐲∈ℝd𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)=𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚𝑯𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})=\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y}) (12)

where 𝐇=∫01∇2F​(𝐲+s​(𝐱−𝐲))​ds𝐇superscriptsubscript01superscript∇2𝐹𝐲𝑠𝐱𝐲differential-d𝑠\bm{H}=\int_{0}^{1}\nabla^{2}F(\bm{y}+s(\bm{x}-\bm{y}))\mathrm{d}s.

Proof.

Due to the linearity of integral, we have

∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)=∫01∇2F​(𝒚+s​(𝒙−𝒚))​(𝒙−𝒚)​ds=𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚).∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚superscriptsubscript01superscript∇2𝐹𝒚𝑠𝒙𝒚𝒙𝒚differential-d𝑠𝑯𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})=\int_{0}^{1}\nabla^{2}F(\bm{y}+s(\bm{x}-\bm{y}))(\bm{x}-\bm{y})\mathrm{d}s=\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y}). (13)

∎

Lemma 2.

Suppose 𝐱𝐱\bm{x} and 𝐲𝐲\bm{y} are random variables with the same random sources ξ𝜉\xi. Then, if a function F𝐹F is L𝐿L-lipschitz smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex, then we have

‖𝔼​[∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)]‖2≥superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚2absent\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}\geq μ2​‖𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚]‖2superscript𝜇2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚2\displaystyle\mu^{2}\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]\right\|^{2} (14)
‖𝔼​[∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)]‖2≤superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚2absent\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}\leq L​⟨𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚],𝔼​[∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)]⟩𝐿𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚\displaystyle L\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})]}\right> (15)
(μ+L)​⟨𝔼​[∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)],𝔼​[(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩≥𝜇𝐿𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚absent\displaystyle(\mu+L)\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>\geq ‖𝔼​[∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)]‖2+μ​L​‖𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚]‖2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚2𝜇𝐿superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚2\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}+\mu L\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]\right\|^{2} (16)
Proof.

Based on lemma 1, we have 𝔼​[∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)]=𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})]={\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]. And hence,

‖𝔼​[∇F​(𝒙)−∇F​(𝒚)]‖2=superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹𝒙∇𝐹𝒚2absent\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\nabla F(\bm{x})-\nabla F(\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}= ⟨𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)],𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right> (17)
=\displaystyle= 𝔼​⟨𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚),𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩.𝔼𝑯𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left<{\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>. (18)

Since μ≼𝑯≼Lprecedes-or-equals𝜇𝑯precedes-or-equals𝐿\mu\preccurlyeq\bm{H}\preccurlyeq L, it follows that

μ​⟨𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚],𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩≤𝔼​⟨𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚),𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩≤L​⟨𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚],𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩.𝜇𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚𝔼𝑯𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚𝐿𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\mu\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>\leq{\mathbb{E}}\left<{\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>\leq L\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>. (19)

Combining 18 and 19, we prove the second inequality in Lemma 2. Furthermore, note that

⟨𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚],𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩=𝔼​⟨𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚],𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)⟩≥μ​𝔼​⟨𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚],(𝒙−𝒚)⟩.𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚𝔼𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚𝑯𝒙𝒚𝜇𝔼𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>={\mathbb{E}}\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})}\right>\geq\mu{\mathbb{E}}\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{(\bm{x}-\bm{y})}\right>. (20)

We have

⟨𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)],𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩≥μ2​⟨𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚],𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚]⟩.𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚superscript𝜇2𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>\geq\mu^{2}\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]}\right>. (21)

This completes the proof of the first inequality in Lemma 2. Using the similar technique as above, one can prove that

‖𝔼​[H​(𝒙−𝒚)−μ​(𝒙−𝒚)]‖2≤superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝐻𝒙𝒚𝜇𝒙𝒚2absent\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[H(\bm{x}-\bm{y})-\mu(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}\leq (L−μ)​⟨𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚],𝔼​[(𝑯−μ​𝑰)​(𝒙−𝒚)]⟩.𝐿𝜇𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝜇𝑰𝒙𝒚\displaystyle(L-\mu)\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[(\bm{H}-\mu\bm{I})(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>. (22)

Besides, note that

‖𝔼​[H​(𝒙−𝒚)−μ​(𝒙−𝒚)]‖2=superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝐻𝒙𝒚𝜇𝒙𝒚2absent\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[H(\bm{x}-\bm{y})-\mu(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}= ‖𝔼​[H​(𝒙−𝒚)]‖2+μ2​‖𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚]‖2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝐻𝒙𝒚2superscript𝜇2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚2\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[H(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}+\mu^{2}\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]\right\|^{2}
−2​μ​⟨𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)],𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚]⟩.2𝜇𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚\displaystyle-2\mu\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]}\right>. (23)

Substituting 23 into 22 and rearranging, we obtain that

(L+μ)​⟨𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)],𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚]⟩≥‖𝔼​[𝑯​(𝒙−𝒚)]‖2+μ​L​‖𝔼​[𝒙−𝒚]‖2.𝐿𝜇𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝑯𝒙𝒚2𝜇𝐿superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]𝒙𝒚2\displaystyle(L+\mu)\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]}\right>\geq\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}+\mu L\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]\right\|^{2}. (24)

Here we complete the proof of the last inequality in Lemma 2. ∎

B.4 Empirical Validations for Adaptive Client Optimizers

While for vanilla SGD client optimizer, we can get the analytical expressions of hi,qisubscriptℎ𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖h_{i},q_{i} in Assumptions 1 and 2, it can be complicated to perform the same analysis for adaptive client optimizers. So in this subsection, we are going to provide some empirical evidence that adaptive optimizers (such as Adam) also satisfies Assumption 1 and can yield smaller hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} values than vanilla SGD.

In particular, we evaluate the performance of vanilla SGD and Adam on the MNIST dataset [34]. For each optimizer, we train two logistic regression models, which start from two different initial points 𝒙,𝒚𝒙𝒚\bm{x},\bm{y} but traverse the same sequence of mini-batches of data. After repeating the same experiment multiple times with different random seeds, we report hi=‖𝔼​[𝒜i​(𝒙;k)]−𝔼​[𝒜i​(𝒚;k)]‖2/‖𝒙−𝒚‖2subscriptℎ𝑖superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝒜𝑖𝒙𝑘𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝒜𝑖𝒚𝑘2superscriptnorm𝒙𝒚2h_{i}=\|{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};k)]-{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{y};k)]\|^{2}/\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|^{2} in Figure 4. One can observe that, given a number of local steps k𝑘k, Adam can have a smaller value of hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} than vanilla SGD.

Appendix D Connection with Previous Works on the Minimizer Inconsistency

When client learning rates, number of local steps are the same across all clients, and non-adaptive, deterministic ClientOpt are used, ‖𝒙~−𝒙∗‖norm~𝒙superscript𝒙\|\widetilde{\bm{x}}-\bm{x}^{*}\| can vanish to zero along with the learning rates. This phenomenon has been observed and analyzed by few recent literature in different forms, see [19, 21, 20]. Theorem 1 generalizes these results by allowing heterogeneous local hyper-parameters and adaptive, stochastic client optimizers. In addition, the non-vanishing bias was studied in [18] by assuming different local learning rates and local steps at clients. In this paper, we further generalize the results by showing that even when the learning rates and local steps are the same, using local adaptive methods will lead to a non-vanishing gap. We summarize the differences in Table 6.

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 2

In the quadratic problem, we can write down the analytical expression of operator 𝒜isubscript𝒜𝑖\mathcal{A}_{i}. Specifically, for the K𝐾K-th local iterate of client i𝑖i, we have

𝒙(k+1)=superscript𝒙𝑘1absent\displaystyle\bm{x}^{(k+1)}= 𝒙(k)−ηi​𝑷i​∇Fi​(𝒙(k))superscript𝒙𝑘subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑷𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒙𝑘\displaystyle\bm{x}^{(k)}-\eta_{i}\bm{P}_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}^{(k)}) (86)
=\displaystyle= 𝒙(k)−ηi​𝑷i​𝑯i​(𝒙(k)−𝒙i∗)superscript𝒙𝑘subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑷𝑖subscript𝑯𝑖superscript𝒙𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖\displaystyle\bm{x}^{(k)}-\eta_{i}\bm{P}_{i}\bm{H}_{i}(\bm{x}^{(k)}-\bm{x}_{i}^{*}) (87)
=\displaystyle= (𝑰−ηi​𝑷i​𝑯i)​(𝒙(k)−𝒙i∗)+𝒙i∗.𝑰subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑷𝑖subscript𝑯𝑖superscript𝒙𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖\displaystyle(\bm{I}-\eta_{i}\bm{P}_{i}\bm{H}_{i})(\bm{x}^{(k)}-\bm{x}_{i}^{*})+\bm{x}_{i}^{*}. (88)

That is,

𝒙(k+1)−𝒙i∗=(𝑰−ηi​𝑷i​𝑯i)k+1​(𝒙−𝒙i∗).superscript𝒙𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖superscript𝑰subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑷𝑖subscript𝑯𝑖𝑘1𝒙superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖\displaystyle\bm{x}^{(k+1)}-\bm{x}_{i}^{*}=(\bm{I}-\eta_{i}\bm{P}_{i}\bm{H}_{i})^{k+1}(\bm{x}-\bm{x}_{i}^{*}). (89)

According to the definition of 𝒜isubscript𝒜𝑖\mathcal{A}_{i}, we have

𝒜​(𝒙)=𝒜𝒙absent\displaystyle\mathcal{A}(\bm{x})= ∑i=1Mwi​[(𝑰−ηi​𝑷i​𝑯i)τi​(𝒙−𝒙i∗)+𝒙i∗].superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖delimited-[]superscript𝑰subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑷𝑖subscript𝑯𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝒙superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}[(\bm{I}-\eta_{i}\bm{P}_{i}\bm{H}_{i})^{\tau_{i}}(\bm{x}-\bm{x}_{i}^{*})+\bm{x}_{i}^{*}]. (91)

We first show that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is contractive. Note that

𝒜​(𝒙)−𝒜​(𝒚)=𝒜𝒙𝒜𝒚absent\displaystyle\mathcal{A}(\bm{x})-\mathcal{A}(\bm{y})= [∑i=1Mwi​(𝑰−ηi​𝑷i​𝑯i)τi]​(𝒙−𝒚).delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscript𝑰subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑷𝑖subscript𝑯𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\left[\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}(\bm{I}-\eta_{i}\bm{P}_{i}\bm{H}_{i})^{\tau_{i}}\right](\bm{x}-\bm{y}). Appendix F Proof for the Convergence of Local Correction

F.1 Main Results

Without loss of generalities, suppose that at the t𝑡t-th round, the local model changes of client i𝑖i can be written as

𝒙(t)−𝒜i​(𝒙(t);τi)=ηi​∑k=0τi−1𝑩i(t,k)​∇Fi​(𝒙i(t,k))superscript𝒙𝑡subscript𝒜𝑖superscript𝒙𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝜂𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\bm{x}^{(t)}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x}^{(t)};\tau_{i})=\eta_{i}\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{B}_{i}^{(t,k)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,k)}) (96)

where ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} is the client learning rate, {𝑩i(t,k)}superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑡𝑘\{\bm{B}_{i}^{(t,k)}\} are symmetric and positive definite matrices, and 𝒙i(t,k)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑡𝑘\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,k)} denotes the local iterate after performing k𝑘k local steps. When the local correction technique is applied, the client will send the following normalized local changes to the server:

𝒉i(t)=1∑k=0τi−1𝑩i(t,k)​∑k=0τi−1𝑩i(t,k)​∇Fi​(𝒙i(t,k)):=∑k=0τi−1𝑨i(t,k)​∇Fi​(𝒙i(t,k))superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑡𝑘assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑨𝑖𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\bm{h}_{i}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{B}_{i}^{(t,k)}}\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{B}_{i}^{(t,k)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,k)}):=\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{A}_{i}^{(t,k)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,k)}) (97)

where 𝑨i(t,k)=𝑩i(t,k)/∑k=0τi−1𝑩i(t,k)superscriptsubscript𝑨𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑡𝑘\bm{A}_{i}^{(t,k)}=\bm{B}_{i}^{(t,k)}/\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{B}_{i}^{(t,k)} and ∑k=0τi−1𝑨i(t,k)=𝑰superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑨𝑖𝑡𝑘𝑰\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{A}_{i}^{(t,k)}=\bm{I}. Then, the server will aggregate the normalized local changes and update the global model as follows

𝒙(t+1)=𝒙(t)−α​∑i=1Mwi​𝒉i(t)superscript𝒙𝑡1superscript𝒙𝑡𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\bm{x}^{(t+1)}=\bm{x}^{(t)}-\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\bm{h}_{i}^{(t)} (98)

where α𝛼\alpha denotes the server learning rate.

Our convergence analysis will be centered around the following assumptions.

Assumption 3.

Each local objective is Lipschitz smooth, that is, ‖∇Fi​(𝐱)−∇Fi​(𝐲)‖≤L​‖𝐱−𝐲‖,∀i∈[M]formulae-sequencenorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐲𝐿norm𝐱𝐲for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑀\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{y})\right\|\leq L\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|,\forall i\in[M].

Assumption 4.

The matrices {𝐀i(t,k)}superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑖𝑡𝑘\{\bm{A}_{i}^{(t,k)}\} are positive-definite symmetric matrices and have bounded operator norm: ‖𝐀i(t,k)‖op≤Λ/τisubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐀𝑖𝑡𝑘opΛsubscript𝜏𝑖\left\|\bm{A}_{i}^{(t,k)}\right\|_{\tiny{\mbox{op}}}\leq\Lambda/\tau_{i}.

Assumption 5.

The pre-conditioned gradients at each local iteration have bounded norm, i.e., ‖𝐁i(t,k)​∇Fi​(𝐱i(t,k))‖≤Gnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐁𝑖𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑡𝑘𝐺\left\|\bm{B}_{i}^{(t,k)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,k)})\right\|\leq G.

Theorem 3 (Convergence Guarantee for Local Correction Technique).

Suppose all clients have the same client learning rate η𝜂\eta and the same number of local sptes τ𝜏\tau. Under Assumptions 3, 4 and 5, if the server learning rate is set as α=η​τ≤1/L𝛼𝜂𝜏1𝐿\alpha=\eta\tau\leq 1/L and the client learning rate is

η=min⁡{1τ​L,1τ​T13​(DL2​Λ​G2)13}𝜂1𝜏𝐿1𝜏superscript𝑇13superscript𝐷superscript𝐿2Λsuperscript𝐺213\displaystyle\eta=\min\left\{\frac{1}{\tau L},\frac{1}{\tau T^{\frac{1}{3}}}\left(\frac{D}{L^{2}\Lambda G^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\right\} (99)

where D=F​(𝐱(0))−Finf𝐷𝐹superscript𝐱0subscript𝐹infD=F(\bm{x}^{(0)})-F_{\text{inf}}, then the global iterate 98 converges at the following rate:

mint∈[0,T]⁡‖∇F​(𝒙(t))‖2=𝒪​(1T+Λ13​G23T23).subscript𝑡0𝑇superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒙𝑡2𝒪1𝑇superscriptΛ13superscript𝐺23superscript𝑇23\displaystyle\min_{t\in[0,T]}\left\|\nabla F(\bm{x}^{(t)})\right\|^{2}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T}+\frac{\Lambda^{\frac{1}{3}}G^{\frac{2}{3}}}{T^{\frac{2}{3}}}\right). (100)

It is worth noting that the convergence rate 100 matches previous results in [39, 40] in the deterministic, non-IID data setting. Theorem 3 shows that using adaptive client optimizers together with local correction can preserve the same convergence rate as vanilla GD client optimizer and there is no non-vanishing solution bias.

F.3 Proof of Theorem 3

Since each local objective is L𝐿L-smooth, we have
